displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Well I know that’s true. Doctor: But that’s a whole ‘nother story. But that way if you do call me one day out of the blue, I’m gonna be like yeah we just checked your hip thing remember and it was a couple months ago and you were fine. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Blood work… Doctor: Might as well get it done. Patient: Blood work everything – can I do that with the Zometa too or when we do the Zometa Doctor: Yeah. Patient: can we do the x-ray the same day? Doctor: Sure. Easy. Patient: Or were you thinking of – you were thinking of doing… Doctor: It doesn’t matter. Whatever. There’s no emergency guys. Whenever is convenient for you. Patient: I see. Okay. Okay. Doctor: So you decide when you want to do it.

Patient: All right. So this is the best. This is the best option that you're thinking right now. Doctor: Mhm. Yeah. It keeps you on things that you haven't really broken through, but your pills are starting to do this. They’re starting to tread water. And I'm like, “Hold up!” before you start to sink. Let me see if we can throw a lifeline. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So a lot of the prostate cancer trials are like that now. So we're like, I'm okay. I'm okay. And then you’re like uh oh I’m starting to fade. And so we have all these new pills that are like, wait- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: - I'm gonna come and help you. Patient: Okay, so. Doctor: Okay. Patient: All right. Doctor: Well, good. It was nice to see you. I'm glad we had a chance to chat and you know, if it's good then call M___ and I’ll tell her to be on the lookout. Patient: Okay. So it's up to me to call her and let her know. Doctor: Well I’ll have her call you too. But that way, you know that at your convenience if you're at work, and she calls you that you can call her back. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I don’t see any reason to cancel that. Family Member: Unless you want to – so it doesn’t matter whether we sign the consent today or that day to you. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So when’s the next time I come in to I guess there? There’s no way of doing it here? Doctor: It’s too much. Family Member: I think it’s a echocardiogram… Healthcare Professional: Phase I. Patient: Can I bring a book? Doctor: Oh yeah, yeah. They even have movies and they have a TV there. Family Member: You’re gonna bring me too. I’m definitely coming to this. Doctor: They have all kinds of stuff to do there.

Patient: Yeah. I’m taking her to lunch. Doctor: That’s nice. Where you guys going? Patient: Downtown somewhere. Doctor: Oh. Did you check out the, the, S___ S___? Do you guys ever go in there? Family Member: No. Doctor: It’s really good. Family Member: Oh. Sounds interesting. Doctor: It’s, it’s, you know, on one of those Zagat books and stuff. Family Member: Right. Doctor: It’s just, they do creative things. It’s not your standard mac and cheese. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: You like it?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Then they mail it to your house Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then when you get it you take four pills a day. Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: If you can, you just call us, call K__ or W__ and go hey we got the medicine Patient: Right. Doctor: that way I know when you started. When you’ve been on it for two or three weeks, you come back to see me and we’ll make sure you’re doing okay. Patient: When I’m doing okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So now okay you know what my next question is… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You know I got that motorcycle.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which why I told J___ let’s give it another whirl before you know you get too… Patient: Yeah absolutely. Doctor: …pooped out from the Taxotere. So I got M_____ on it. I’m just trying to look at your ankles over there. Just swelling more or what’s? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh, it’s just your socks. Okay. Patient: Just socks. She was checking I think for swelling. Doctor: Yeah. She’s pretty good. Patient: In fact I think um Doctor: Okay Patient: Dr. S____ put me on um oh what is it? It’s a, it must be a diuretic, but it’s I can tell you… Doctor: Mmm. Oh hydrochlorothiazide or Lasix? Patient: It’s not a Lasix or at least I don’t know (sound of zipper)

Patient: I know. Okay. Family Member: Um. Healthcare Professional: Let me get your reports copied. Family Member: Do you mind if we, is it possible to sit in here and read through the consent? Just so we have… Doctor: That’s fine. It’s just that do you want to - are you okay with doing that? Patient: No, no, let’s take our time. Family Member: Okay. Alright. I didn’t mean not to take it home- Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: -but I meant if questions come up we could ask them. Doctor: Oh I see what you mean. Family Member: Let’s read it through in here and see if we have questions. I’m not asking you to sign it. Doctor: Yeah. Okay and then that way you – you know I’ll check back with you if you have questions.

Family Member: If you could maybe have somebody Google or you Google fluorescence and just see what it’s got that wild Doctor: Okay. Patient: Flor-essence. Doctor: Okay. Flor-essence. Done. Nice to see you. Hello. Hello. Hello. And Good-bye. Do you have enough to eat and drink? Feeling better? Patient: So. Yeah. Oh. I wanted to go to Hospital DR. How do I get to Hospital DR from here? How do I get to DR from here? Can I get a navigator? Doctor: Oh. Yeah a navigator. I couldn’t explain it if my life depended on it, and I’ve been here fourteen years. Doctor: Bye guys. I’m happy you can get Family Member: Bye.

Family Member: Oh my god! Doctor: When I say we got to get insurance right, we got to get insurance right. But we also, they don’t mix it; they don’t pop the tab unless you’re around because there’s no re-do. Once you (makes sound) Family Member: So, so. Is this going to make him sleepless, like you said a little more energy? Doctor: No, no, it’s only going to help with pain and I think when you get off the Xtandi you’ll actually have more energy because no matter what that Xtandi is making you tired. Patient: Well my energy level isn’t bad. Doctor: Yeah, to you, but we’ve got this one over here going “Heh?” (Chuckles) Family Member: Well he’s been pretty active. Patient: No, I’ve been pretty active. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He’ll fall asleep on a dime, but so do I. Doctor: Me, too. Now I wish I had a clinical study to offer you at this point, but our Xofigo plus something requires your disease to actually be worse than it is (not that I’m wishing you were on that) Patient: Right.

Patient: No, no. Doctor: Bowels working okay? Patient: Yep. Family Member: But it went from one side to the other which and he does have kidney stones, but last night it was on this side, this morning that one stopped and it was on this side. Doctor: And now it’s gone? Patient: Yeah. I had a little bit over here on this side, but I mean I think it’s my back because I’ve had back… Family Member: Because kidneys wouldn’t do that. It wouldn’t push back and forth like that. Doctor: No and if it’s the lymph nodes that are pushing, there may be a little bit of pain from that. Family Member: From one side to the other but.. Doctor: Yeah. But it’s still, it doesn’t sound cancer related. It almost sounds muscle or… Family Member: I think his back’s out of whack. Doctor: Or back.

Family Member: Okay. We’re done. Doctor: I think so. I never did this before. This is my first time. So. Family Member: Okay. Patient: This was on film? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Oh. Doctor: We’re supposed to be talking about clinical trials which I think we did; although, we didn’t enroll you in one. Patient: No, you answered my questions. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You answered my questions. Doctor: But, I think, uh, the study is looking at how we talk about clinical trials, and, I think there is a racial component looking at --- Patient: Yeah, there is –

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The Venlafaxine or Effexor for mood – thirty-seven and a half. Patient: I don’t know. I don’t know. What’s another name for it? Doctor: Venlafaxine or Effexor. Patient: Oh yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, I do, yeah. Doctor: And the Enzalutamide, you’re still taking four pills a day? Patient: Xtandi? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And the Zofran, you take it as needed. Anything else that I need to add to this list, that we don’t have on this list? Patient: No. No. Doctor: Nothing for moving your bowels, slow your bowels down? Family Member: Oh you don’t do that

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so you’re set there. And there’s probably nobody out there right now. Patient: Right. Doctor: I always end up with you late in the day. Doctor: At least you don’t have to go to the ER tonight. Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? So then I’ll let you head out and, huh, we’ll check on whether the trial makes sense. So I’ll say, read the consents, we will review your records to see if eligible, because if you need blood, I can give you a blood transfusion, but the hep C we may not be able to. Patient: Right. Doctor: This tells you, you know, you can read the consent. We’ll review your records to see if you’re eligible. Otherwise, we can start the chemo in a few weeks. Stop the abiraterone now. Continue on the prednisone. It says stop the abiraterone, and it tells you on this page that I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then it says that, huh, I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m thinking four to six weeks will give us at least an inkling if it’s doing something. Even if it’s stabilizes the PSA. We kind of have a clue that it’s doing what it’s supposed to. But to give it a fair trial, typically six to twelve weeks is required on any new medication I would say. Patient: Do you think that in the meantime the cancer will increase? Doctor: It seems very unlikely to me. Okay. Mainly because your scans haven’t changed. If they had… Patient: Except for the brightness. Doctor: Except for the brightness, yeah. If they had changed, you know if you had three new spots now, we would probably be having a different discussion. We’d say well I think we need to – got to go to chemotherapy or something that will work quickly or maybe Lynparza give that a try. But I think we have room to wait and see if we can squeeze any effect from the Xtandi if that is the resistance pathway that your cancer is stuck at which… Family Member: Mm Hmm. Patient: Yeah Lupron continues regardless of any of the options? Doctor: No matter what that continues and then we add other things on top. Patient: Even with the PARP inhibitor or the chemo? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Lupron goes with the chemo? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: In general, for PSMA therapy experimental. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Although I can’t say that it is not cases that can be worse. Each Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So for example if you did have three spots and your insurance company Patient: I’m not one. Doctor: Yeah. Exactly. Patient: It’s amazing uh well one thing I’m really fortunate with is that um I’m at a state of mind where I just that kind of helps me when I’m making decisions. So it’s not like Doctor: is that cancer care has become so expensive. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: companies charge for their services
